Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Biomass estimation and uncertainty analysis: Integrating Bayesian modeling and small-footprint waveform LiDAR data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Remote sensing is used to characterize and map the spatial variationÂ of Earth's vegetation and its changes over time. A relatively new airborne laser sensor called LiDAR (Light Detection And Ranging) has been used to accurately characterize the three-dimensional vegetation structure and to measure plant biomass and carbon content. With increased LiDAR data availability, there is a need to develop open source tools for processing these data effectively to obtain the vegetation and terrain information. With current methods, substantial variation and uncertainty remain in estimating the amount and type of vegetation. Support from this Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant (DDIG) will be used to develop open source tools to process LiDAR data from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) and to explore their potential for use in identifying tree species, estimating vegetation amounts, and determining the statistical uncertainty in the analysis. The methods developed from this project will facilitate the creation of 3D-vegetation structure and enable the understanding of ecosystem patterns and processes. The quantification of errors and uncertainties of vegetation structure and amount are also conducive to designing effective plans for sustainable forest management and providing accurate inputs for biogeochemical models to inform science-based policy.

This research will be accomplished through the following steps: (1) Develop algorithms and open source tools for LiDAR data processing, (2) Segment individual trees and identify tree species with raw LiDAR data alone using Random forests and Bayesian machine learning method, (3) Build different models (step-wise, Random forests, and hierarchical Bayesian models) to estimate forest biomass and carbon stocks using LiDAR metrics and variables derived from point clouds, and (4) Quantify the uncertainty of estimations in different processing stages based on different approaches and model parameters. The algorithms and processing methodologies developed in this proposal will provide open source tools for LiDAR waveform processing and enhance the use and value of NEON data. Moreover, the products of this research will assist forest managers to better manage precious natural resources and make more informed decisions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Remote sensing is one of the core technologies for observing Earth’s vegetation and its dynamics over time. The advent of new airborne and spaceborne LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) collecting small-footprint full waveform (FW) and photon counting LiDAR data over the Earth’s vegetation and terrain has demonstrated their increasing abilities of accurately characterizing the three-dimensional vegetation structure and quantifying biomass and carbon stocks. With increased data availability, there is a need to develop open source tools for effectively processing these new types of LiDAR data to derive vegetation and terrain information. Moreover, substantial variation and uncertainty remain in the vegetation characterization and biomass estimation with current methods. Therefore, this research developed open source tools to process FW (from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON)) and to explore their potential in real-world applications such as tree species identification with uncertainty analysis. This undoubtedly increased the value of the NEON data and expanded their data potential for applications for characterizing three-dimensional vegetation structure. The methods developed from this project will enable ecology scientists to more easily access the 3D vegetation structure, advance our understanding of ecosystem patterns and processes and hold the potential to become a benchmark for further method adjustment. The quantification of errors and uncertainties of vegetation structure and forest biomass estimation are also conducive to designing effective plans for sustainable forest management and providing accurate inputs for biogeochemical models to inform science-based policy.

This research accomplished the following steps: (1) Developed algorithms and open source tools for small-footprint FW LiDAR data processing, (2) Applied the Bayesian non-linear modeling concepts for waveform decomposition and quantified the propagation of error and uncertainty along the processing steps, and (3) Segmented individual trees and identified tree species with different sources of data such as raw FW LiDAR data, waveform-based point cloud using Random Forests and the Bayesian machine learning methods. One important output of our project is an R package made available through GitHub to allow a wide dissemination of our algorithm and facilitate the adoption of our advanced processing methods by scientists using full waveform lidar data for ecological applications. Finally, multiple peer-reviewed publications have been published or are planned for submission to top-ranked remote sensing and ecology journals to benefit the scientific community.
